title: The Vatican's influential apostles of peace
summary: Wielding a powerful diplomatic apparatus, Pope Francis is closely involved in world affairs, with priorities that include re-establishing dialogue between warring parties in Gaza and Ukraine.

title: The Iran-Israel escalation mirrors 1991 Iraq crisis
summary: After Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein launched strikes against Israel in 1991, US President George H. W. Bush forbade any form of Israeli retaliation. That move enabled the launch of an Arab-Israeli peace process.

title: Argentina: 'President Milei's political project is based on a selective, fantasized account of the past'
summary: Historians Ernesto Bohoslavsky, Marianne Gonzalez Aleman and Nadia Tahir analyze the relationship between the Argentine head of state and his country's history, aiming to provide deeper insights into his governmental decisions.

title: Ukraine says it struck a Russian ship, Russia claims advances
summary: Ukraine said its navy put a Russian ship out of service in annexed Crimea. Meanwhile, Russia said it had gained territory near the battleground town of Chasiv Yar.

title: Political scientist Anja Durovic: 'Marine Le Pen has won the loyalty of female voters'
summary: On the 80th anniversary of French women's right to vote, political scientist Anja Durovic analyzes voting trends by gender. France stands out in Europe because Marine Le Pen performs better among female voters than other far-right politicians.

title: In the French Alps, the disappearing glacier and 'last chance tourists'
summary: A new gondola lift, opened in February, provides easier access to the endangered Mer de Glace glacier. Site managers are keen to enhance the glacier's appeal, even if it means accepting the paradox between mass tourism and climate change awareness.

title: Colombia: Hundreds of thousands protest President Gustavo Petro
summary: Protesters in Colombia's major cities demonstrated on Sunday against President Petro's healthcare reforms and ongoing violence that undermines peace talks with guerrilla groups.

title: Rockets launched from Iraq target US-led coalition base in Syria
summary: The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights accused the Islamic Resistance in Iraq of staging the attack.

title: Ligue 1: PSG dominate Lyon to close in on league title
summary: Goncalo Ramos scored twice as Paris Saint-German crushed Lyon 4-1 on Sunday. The defending Ligue 1 champions are now 11 points clear of Monaco and can secure a 10th French title in 12 seasons on Wednesday against Lorient.

title: Maldives: Pro-China president's party wins big in parliamentary election
summary: President Mohamed Muizzu's People's National Congress (PNC) secured 66 of the first 86 declared seats, achieving a super-majority in the 93-member parliament.

title: Javier Milei and Elon Musk are giga happy. Does anyone care?
summary: On April 12, the Argentine president and Tesla CEO visited the company's gigafactory in Austin, Texas for an opportunity to discuss business freely.

title: Iran's Khamenei praises 'success' of military after Israel attack
summary: In his first comments since Iran's attack against Israel, Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei said 'the issue of the number of missiles fired or the missiles that hit the target' was 'secondary.'

title: US House of Representatives passes new aid package for Ukraine after six months of deadlock
summary: Four bills were passed on Saturday addressing aid to Kyiv, Israel and Taiwan, and the potential ban on TikTok.

title: London Marathon: Jepchirchir and Munyao secure Kenyan double
summary: Olympic champion Peres Jepchirchir beat the world record for a marathon without male pacemakers.

title: Cuba: Land of boxing and the French team's training ground
summary: The French boxing team spent two weeks on the Caribbean island for a training camp, where they had the chance to compete against some of the world's best amateur boxers.

title: Christophe Pottier, archaeologist: 'Angkor must have looked like a big garden'
summary: Now in charge of the Ecole Française d'Extrême-Orient in Chiang Mai, Thailand, the archaeologist worked for 18 years at Angkor, focusing on the site's urban occupants and its cartography.

title: One dead, seven missing after two Japanese military helicopters crash
summary: The helicopters appear to have crashed during night-time training of countering submarines off the Izu Islands in the Pacific Ocean, officials said.

title: Cambodia's 'Mona Lisa,' a large bronze statue of Vishnu, is due to be examined in Paris
summary: The smiling statue of the god Vishnu will undergo a thorough analysis, as well as a slight facelift, by researchers between its May departure from Cambodia and the opening of Paris' Guimet Museum of Asian Arts' exhibition on Khmer bronzes on April 30, 2025.

title: American troops withdrawing from Niger while facing pressure from Chad
summary: Washington's announcement on Friday that it is withdrawing 1,100 soldiers from the Agadez base in Niger marks the loss of a strategic point for intelligence operations on armed groups in the Sahel, coinciding with Russia's growing influence in the region.

title: Canadian uranium is strategic for French nuclear power plants
summary: The Cigar Lake mine in the heart of Saskatchewan is one of the world's richest in uranium. The McClean Lake mill, which processes it, is operated by a subsidiary of France's Orano and sells 40% of its production to French multinational electric utility company, EDF.

title: Ecuador: Prison chief murdered amid national vote on anti-crime measures
summary: Ecuadorians on Sunday voted on measures to expand military and police powers, boost gun control and impose harsher penalties in response to widespread gang activity.
